title: Ginsburg: Supreme Court Work Keeps Me Going After Latest Bout With Cancer
text:
WASHINGTON—Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg sought Saturday to dispel concerns over her health, telling a packed audience at the National Book Festival that she was readying to plunge into the Supreme Court term opening in October.

The 86-year-old justice recently completed a three-week course of radiation treatment for a malignant tumor on her pancreas, the fourth time the Supreme Court’s oldest member has been treated for cancer.

“This audience can see that I am alive,” Justice Ginsburg quipped, drawing riotous applause from a crowd estimated at 4,000. “And I’m on my way to being very well.”

Although she canceled a planned summer visit to Santa Fe, N.M., Justice Ginsburg has maintained an active public schedule. She is to speak Tuesday at the University of Arkansas. All 16,000 tickets for the event, at the Verizon Arena, in North Little Rock, Ark., have been distributed. Thousands of people remain on the waiting list.

Rather than weary her, the demands of the Supreme Court have helped her through health problems, Justice Ginsburg said.

“It’s the best and the hardest job that I ever had, and it has kept me going through four cancer bouts,” she said. “Instead of concentrating on my aches and pains I know that I have to…surmount whatever is going on in my body and concentrate on the court’s work.”

Justice Ginsburg didn’t comment directly on recent cases, but she did discuss her 2015 opinion, by a 5-4 vote, upholding the constitutionality of state-created commissions to draw legislative and congressional districts. In the wake of the court’s June decision, also 5-4, that partisan gerrymanders cannot be challenged in federal court, state-based measures remain the only practical avenue to curb such practices.

“Something needed to be done about the partisan gerrymander,” Justice Ginsburg said Saturday. “There was very little incentive to vote, because your district had been rigged” by partisan majorities in the state legislature to elect either a Democrat or a Republican rather than hold communities together or create competitive races, she said.

In 2000, Arizona voters approved a ballot initiative that transferred redistricting power to an independent commission. The state legislature sued, contending that it alone could draw the maps under the constitutional provision providing that each state’s legislature should prescribe “the times, places and manner of holding elections.”

Justice Ginsburg’s opinion reasoned that, in giving voters direct lawmaking power through the initiative process, states such as Arizona had made the people themselves the legislature.

The interviewer, NPR correspondent Nina Totenberg, observed that Chief Justice John Roberts, who wrote the June opinion rejecting federal remedies for partisan gerrymanders, had pointed to state voter initiatives as a possible alternative to curb the practice—despite having dissented from Justice Ginsburg’s 2015 opinion.

“As one lives, one learns,” Justice Ginsburg said. “I think the chief learned he was wrong in the Arizona case.” Ms. Ginsburg dissented from the June opinion.

Justice Ginsburg appeared at the book festival, an annual event organized by the Library of Congress, in connection with “My Own Words,” a collection of her writings from eighth grade through her Supreme Court years. It was compiled by Georgetown law professors Mary Hartnett and Wendy Williams, who joined the justice on stage. The two have been working on her authorized biography since 2004.

Ms. Williams said the pair typically interviewed Justice Ginsburg for the biography each year for three days at the end of August. This year was different, she said, because of Ms. Ginsburg’s treatment at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. “She remembered everything and she was perfectly normal, but she was very tired” during two days of interviews in New York, Ms. Williams said. “And then we came down yesterday and did our third day” in Washington.

Ms. Hartnett said they had expected the biography to have been published before the writing collection, to “break the story of Justice Ginsburg.” Instead, the justice’s career broke out on its own when she reached her 80s, exploding as pop culture’s Notorious RBG. She has been portrayed in movies and as a recurring character on “Saturday Night Live” and entered a feminist pantheon for decades of effort to secure equal rights for women.

The biographers now intend to tell the full, complete story, of Justice Ginsburg, Ms. Hartnett said. “Hopefully it will not come out very soon,” she added.
